channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: American Firm, Starwood, Signs Deal to Manage Hotels in Cuba
item.description: The agreement, inked the day before President Obama arrives, will make this the first American chain to run hotels on the island in more than 50 years.
item.dc:creator: VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: The Hotel Quinta Avenida in Havana is one of the hotels in Cuba that Starwood has signed a deal to refurbish and manage.

item.title: A View of ISIS’s Evolution in New Details of Paris Attacks
item.description: A 55-page French report details how the attackers used disciplined communications, identified soft targets and perfected bomb-making techniques after two years of failures.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI, ALISSA J. RUBIN and LAURE FOUQUET
item.media:description: A wounded man was evacuated at the Bataclan concert hall during the Paris attacks in November. Investigators hope the arrest of Salah Abdeslam will shed new light on the assaults.

item.title: Colombian Children Pay High Price Amid Peace Talks, U.N. Says
item.description: A quarter-million were displaced and 1,000 were recruited by nonstate combatants during the last three years of negotiations.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Sanctions Eased, Iran Sends Black Market a Strategic Warning
item.description: A billionaire businessman’s death sentence signals a crackdown on violators, but Iran still needs underground networks in order to recoup money and generate trade despite remaining obstacles.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:description: Babak Zanjani, a sanctions-busting Iranian billionaire who was sentenced to death by a Tehran court this month.

item.title: Chefs’ Camaraderie Lifts Basque Cuisine
item.description: A region of tight-knit traditions with a passion for fine ingredients stands apart as an incubator of quality chefs and innovation.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Arnau Bach for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at the Basque Culinary Center in San Sebastián, Spain. The school will offer a doctoral course in gastronomic sciences.

item.title: Man Tied to Hindu Vigilante Group Among 5 Held in Deaths of 2 Muslims
item.description: Two cattle traders were leading oxen to be sold at a fair when they were spotted by a Hindu man who believed they were leading the animals to slaughter, the police in India said.
item.dc:creator: SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: U.S. Marine Killed by Islamic State Rocket Attack in Iraq
item.description: The assault on a coalition base in the north resulted in the second combat death for the United States since it first struck ISIS in 2014.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

item.title: Obama Hopes Cuba Visit Can Be Harbinger of Political Change
item.description: Mr. Obama’s trip represents the start of a new era of engagement between the United States and Cuba, but it also underscores the countries’ deep disagreements.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: An American in Havana near images of Raúl Castro, Cuba’s leader, and President Obama.

item.title: Paris Suspect Claims He ‘Backed Out’ of Stadium Bombing, Prosecutor Says
item.description: Salah Abdeslam, wounded in a shootout with the Brussels police, is thought to be the last surviving member of the group that carried out deadly attacks on Paris in November.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Security forces guard a street leading to the federal police headquarters where captured fugitive Salah Abdeslam appeared before a judge in Brussels, Belgium.

item.title: Paris Suspect Claims He ‘Backed Out’ of Stadium Bombing, Prosecutor Says
item.description: Salah Abdeslam, wounded in a shootout with the Brussels police, is thought to be the last surviving member of the group that carried out deadly attacks on Paris in November.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: Security forces guard a street leading to the federal police headquarters where captured fugitive Salah Abdeslam appeared before a judge in Brussels, Belgium.

item.title: Istanbul Bombing Kills at Least 4 and Wounds Dozens
item.description: A suicide bomber on Saturday struck a street popular with tourists, officials said. Tensions were already high in Turkey after two bombings in Ankara.
item.dc:creator: SAFAK TIMUR and CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: Congo Clamps Down for Election
item.description: The Republic of Congo’s government has ordered the country’s two largest telecommunications providers to block all communication during a presidential election on Sunday for security reasons.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Migrants Lament as Deal With Turkey Closes Door to Europe
item.description: For Europe, a new deal with Turkey offers its best chance to contain a crisis, but for migrants there is a sense that Europe, so welcoming last summer, is betraying them, and that Turkey is benefiting on the backs of their misery.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants wait under the rain in Athens, Greece, Saturday, March 12, 2016.

item.title: Q. And A.: The Culture of Rape Within ISIS, and the Questions That Arise
item.description: Excerpts from a live discussion concerning the systematic rape and sexual slavery of Yazidi women and young girls held captive by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BOBBY ELLIS
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A former sex slave of different Islamic State men, right, wept as she said goodbye to her aunt before leaving Iraq for Germany.

item.title: Wind Given as Possible Cause of Fatal Plane Crash in Russia
item.description: All 55 passengers and seven crew members died when a United Arab Emirates plane crashed in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.media:description: Emergency workers and forensic investigators search the wreckage of a flydubai passenger jet which crashed, killing all 62 people on board, on Saturday in Russia.

item.title: Get Ready, Internet. The Pope Has Joined Instagram.
item.description: The pontiff, formerly known as Jorge Mario Bergoglio, is going by the Instagram name @Franciscus.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: People taking photographs of Pope Francis with their phones in New York in September.

item.title: FlyDubai Plane Crashes at Russian Airport, Killing Over 60
item.description: All 55 passengers and seven crew members aboard died when the Dubai airliner crashed in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don, Russian officials said.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.media:credit: Russia Emergency Ministry, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Emergency workers at the crash site at Rostov-on-Don, Russia, on Saturday.

item.title: Plane Crashes in Russia, All 61 People on Board Killed
item.description: Russian officials said on Saturday that all 61 people on board a passenger jet flying from Dubai to southern Russia were killed when their plane crashed on its second attempt to land at Rostov-on-Don airport.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Prominent Tory Quits British Cabinet Over Welfare Cuts
item.description: The resignation of Iain Duncan Smith as Britain underscored tensions in the government of Prime Minister David Cameron over European Union membership.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Iain Duncan Smith, work and pensions secretary, objected to limits on disability benefits.

item.title: Amid Scandals, Senior Judge in Brazil Suspends Ex-President’s Cabinet Nomination
item.description: The ruling was the latest twist in a political crisis that has Latin America’s largest country’s on edge.
item.dc:creator: VINOD SREEHARSHA
item.media:description: A Brazilian protester holding up a photo of former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva in Rio de Janeiro on Friday.
